title: Charles Shawe
text:
Charles Shawe (15 November 1878 – 9 February 1951) was an <a href="English%20people">English</a> first-class <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er.
The son of Henry Cunliffe Shawe and his wife, Georgina Wilmot Gresley, he was born at <a href="Weddington%20Castle">Weddington Hall</a> in <a href="Warwickshire">Warwickshire</a>. Shawe attended the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>, graduating into the <a href="Rifle%20Brigade%20%28The%20Prince%20Consort%27s%20Own%29">Rifle Brigade</a> as a <a href="Second_lieutenant%23United_Kingdom_%26amp%3B_other_Commonwealth_countries">second lieutenant</a> in 1898. He was promoted to the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in April 1900, with promotion to the rank of <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> coming in April 1904. He was seconded for service as "<a href="aide-de-camp">aide-de-camp</a>" to <a href="Neville%20Lyttelton">General Lyttelton</a> in May 1908. He later served as the "aide-de-camp" to <a href="Arthur%20Foljambe%2C%202nd%20Earl%20of%20Liverpool">Arthur Foljambe, 2nd Earl of Liverpool</a> in November 1912. He retired from active service in November 1913, at which point he was transferred to the <a href="Army%20Reserve%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Reserve of Officers</a>. Shawe returned to active service during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, serving on the general staff. 
Shawe later made a single appearance in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for <a href="H.%20D.%20G.%20Leveson%20Gower">H. D. G. Leveson Gower's XI</a> against <a href="Oxford%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Oxford University</a> at <a href="The%20Saffrons">Eastbourne</a> in 1919. Batting once in the match, Shawe was dismissed <a href="duck%20%28cricket%29">without scoring</a> in the H. D. G. Leveson Gower's XI first-innings by <a href="Frederic%20Waldock">Frederic Waldock</a>, while in the Oxford second-innings he bowled two <a href="over%20%28cricket%29">overs</a>, which conceded 32 runs. He died in February 1951 at <a href="Witham%20Friary">Witham Friary, Somerset</a>.
